elements.content: A metal–organic framework (MOF), {[Co3(ip)3(1,3-bpeb)4]·H2O} n (1), with multiple photoreactive centers, was synthesized via hydrothermal reaction of Co­(II) ion with isophthalate and 1,3-bis­[2-(4-pyridyl)­ethenyl]­benzene (1,3-bpeb) at 180 °C. The MOF 1 was characterized by single-crystal X-ray crystallography and spectroscopic techniques. Its photochemical response under UV irradiation was investigated in detail. An unusual sequence of single-crystal-to-single-crystal reactions was observed as a function of irradiation time. The consecutive reactions were characterized as a [2 + 2] dimerization (D 1) of a particular pair of CC bonds of 1,3-bpeb ligands (Pair A) followed by a conformational isomerization (I) and [2 + 2] dimerization (D 2) of an adjacent pair of 1,3-bpeb ligands (Pair B). The isomerization (I) was instantaneous. The demarcation point for the D 1-ID 2 sequence was the completion of D 1 and the commencement of D 2 at 0.644 h of irradiation. The most striking feature observed is the domino effect triggered by Pair A at the demarcation point, resulting in the isomerization and dimerization of Pair B. The triggering mechanism is believed to be stereochemical in nature.
elements.clean_text: A metal-organic framework (MOF), {[Co3(ip)3(1,3-bpeb)4]⋅H2O} n  (1), with multiple photoreactive centers, was synthesized via hydrothermal reaction of Co(II) ion with isophthalate and 1,3-bis[2-(4-pyridyl)ethenyl]benzene (1,3-bpeb) at 180 °C. The MOF 1 was characterized by single-crystal X-ray crystallography and spectroscopic techniques. Its photochemical response under UV irradiation was investigated in detail. An unusual sequence of single-crystal-to-single-crystal reactions was observed as a function of irradiation time. The consecutive reactions were characterized as a [2 + 2] dimerization (D 1) of a particular pair of CC bonds of 1,3-bpeb ligands (Pair A) followed by a conformational isomerization (I) and [2 + 2] dimerization (D 2) of an adjacent pair of 1,3-bpeb ligands (Pair B). The isomerization (I) was instantaneous. The demarcation point for the D 1-ID 2 sequence was the completion of D 1 and the commencement of D 2 at 0.644 h of irradiation. The most striking feature observed is the domino effect triggered by Pair A at the demarcation point, resulting in the isomerization and dimerization of Pair B. The triggering mechanism is believed to be stereochemical in nature.

elements.content:
The dimerization of a particular pair of CC bonds of the ligands triggers a conformational isomerization of a ligand and the dimerization in the adjacent pair of ligands.

Topochemistry is a research field of current interest. Together with X-ray crystallography, topochemistry can discover correlations between structures of reactants vs products, mechanistic details (such as symmetry, rate, and energetics) of photochemical reactions, and so forth. Understanding ways molecules interact in crystals and how they respond to stimuli such as light allow the design of crystal packing motifs ideal for rational synthesis of difficult-to-synthesize molecules via solid-state reactions. Particular examples are the syntheses of optically pure chiral molecules or polymers via Single-Crystal-to-Single-Crystal (SCSC) reactions.
elements.clean_text:
The dimerization of a particular pair of CC bonds of the ligands triggers a conformational isomerization of a ligand and the dimerization in the adjacent pair of ligands.

Topochemistry is a research field of current interest. Together with X-ray crystallography, topochemistry can discover correlations between structures of reactants vs products, mechanistic details (such as symmetry, rate, and energetics) of photochemical reactions, and so forth. Understanding ways molecules interact in crystals and how they respond to stimuli such as light allow the design of crystal packing motifs ideal for rational synthesis of difficult-to-synthesize molecules via solid-state reactions. Particular examples are the syntheses of optically pure chiral molecules or polymers via Single-Crystal-to-Single-Crystal (SCSC) reactions.

elements.content: Molecules with more than one olefin group can act as versatile ligands, forming interesting MOF structures ideal for SCSC topochemical reactions. Organic ligands such as 1,4-bis­[2-(4-pyridyl)­ethenyl]­benzene (1,4-bpeb) and 1,3-bis­[2-(4-pyridyl)­ethenyl]­benzene (1,3-bpeb) are good candidates in this regard.
elements.clean_text: Molecules with more than one olefin group can act as versatile ligands, forming interesting MOF structures ideal for SCSC topochemical reactions. Organic ligands such as 1,4-bis[2-(4-pyridyl)ethenyl]benzene (1,4-bpeb) and 1,3-bis[2-(4-pyridyl)ethenyl]benzene (1,3-bpeb) are good candidates in this regard.

elements.content: We report herein the synthesis and structure of a new metal–organic framework (MOF) system, namely, {[Co3(ip)3(1,3-bpeb)4]·H2O} n (1) where ip = isophthalate and 1,3-bpeb = 1,3-bis­[2-(4-pyridyl)­ethenyl]­benzene (). It consists of Co­(II) ion, isophthalate (ip2–), and (1,3-bpeb); the latter has multiple photoreactive centers. The structure contains seven photoreactive centers which are potentially capable of undergoing [2 + 2] photodimerization. The progress of the dimerizations of the 1,3-bpeb ligands in SCSC photochemical reactions was monitored by single-crystal X-ray crystallography which provided a series of snapshots of the structures as a function of irradiation time. In this manner, details of the photochemical reactions can be probed. As we shall see, the present MOF system undergoes two photodimerization reactions, one after another, interlaced with an isomerization reaction in between. Interestingly, the relationship between the three reactions is a cooperative one, with the first dimerization occurring at one of the 1,3-bpeb ligands, which triggers the isomerization of another, enabling it to dimerize.
elements.clean_text: We report herein the synthesis and structure of a new metal-organic framework (MOF) system, namely, {[Co3(ip)3(1,3-bpeb)4]⋅H2O} n  (1) where ip = isophthalate and 1,3-bpeb = 1,3-bis[2-(4-pyridyl)ethenyl]benzene (). It consists of Co(II) ion, isophthalate (ip2-), and (1,3-bpeb); the latter has multiple photoreactive centers. The structure contains seven photoreactive centers which are potentially capable of undergoing [2 + 2] photodimerization. The progress of the dimerizations of the 1,3-bpeb ligands in SCSC photochemical reactions was monitored by single-crystal X-ray crystallography which provided a series of snapshots of the structures as a function of irradiation time. In this manner, details of the photochemical reactions can be probed. As we shall see, the present MOF system undergoes two photodimerization reactions, one after another, interlaced with an isomerization reaction in between. Interestingly, the relationship between the three reactions is a cooperative one, with the first dimerization occurring at one of the 1,3-bpeb ligands, which triggers the isomerization of another, enabling it to dimerize.

elements.content:
Color coded.

MOF 1 was synthesized by hydrothermal method (see SI for details) and was characterized by single-crystal X-ray crystallography and spectroscopic techniques (Figures S1–S13). It crystallizes in a triclinic unit cell with space group P1̅. The asymmetric unit consists of three Co2+ ions, three ip2– dianions, and four 1,3-bpeb ligands, in addition to one lattice water molecule. Each pair of Co2+ ions (Co1 ∼ Co2 or Co3 ∼ Co3ii) is bridged by pairs of carboxylates from two different ip2– ligands to form the dimer unit. (Co1 ∼ Co2) unit is further connected to one pair of 1,3-bpeb ligands coordinated on one end only (hereafter denoted as 1c-bpeb) and one pair of 1,3-bpeb ligands coordinated with both ends (hereafter denoted as 2c-bpeb), while (Co3 ∼ Co3ii) unit is connected to two pairs of 2c-bpeb ().
elements.clean_text:
a Color coded.  

MOF 1 was synthesized by hydrothermal method (see SI for details) and was characterized by single-crystal X-ray crystallography and spectroscopic techniques (Figures S1-S13). It crystallizes in a triclinic unit cell with space group P1̅. The asymmetric unit consists of three Co2+ ions, three ip2- dianions, and four 1,3-bpeb ligands, in addition to one lattice water molecule. Each pair of Co2+ ions (Co1 ~ Co2 or Co3 ~ Co3ii) is bridged by pairs of carboxylates from two different ip2- ligands to form the dimer unit. (Co1 ~ Co2) unit is further connected to one pair of 1,3-bpeb ligands coordinated on one end only (hereafter denoted as 1c-bpeb) and one pair of 1,3-bpeb ligands coordinated with both ends (hereafter denoted as 2c-bpeb), while (Co3 ~ Co3ii) unit is connected to two pairs of 2c-bpeb ().

elements.content: Structure of 1: (a) before and (b) after 9 h UV irradiation. (H atoms are omitted for clarity. Symmetry codes: i –x+1, −y+1, −z+1; ii −x+1, −y, −z; iii x+1, y–1, z; iv −x, −y+1, −z; v x–1, y+1, z).
elements.clean_text: 1  Structure of 1: (a) before and (b) after 9 h UV irradiation. (H atoms are omitted for clarity. Symmetry codes: i -x+1, -y+1, -z+1; ii -x+1, -y, -z; iii x+1, y-1, z; iv -x, -y+1, -z; v x-1, y+1, z).

elements.content: In the crystal structure of 1, every (Co3 ∼ Co3ii) unit is linked to two (Co1 ∼ Co2) units by pairs of ip2– along the crystallographic [0 1 1] direction to form a {(Co1 ∼ Co2)-ip2-(Co3 ∼ Co3)-ip2-(Co1 ∼ Co2)­ip2} n chain. The chain is further linked to adjacent chains by two pairs of 2c-bpeb bridging ligands to form a brick-wall-like 2D net parallel to (1 1 1̅) plane (Figure S14). The (Co1 ∼ Co2) unit acts as a T-shaped node; the (Co3 ∼ Co3ii) unit acts as a four-connecting node. Finally, the 2D sheets stack along the crystallographic a axis to complete the crystal structure.
elements.clean_text: In the crystal structure of 1, every (Co3 ~ Co3ii) unit is linked to two (Co1 ~ Co2) units by pairs of ip2- along the crystallographic [0 1 1] direction to form a {(Co1 ~ Co2)-ip2-(Co3 ~ Co3)-ip2-(Co1 ~ Co2)ip2} n  chain. The chain is further linked to adjacent chains by two pairs of 2c-bpeb bridging ligands to form a brick-wall-like 2D net parallel to (1 1 1̅) plane (Figure S14). The (Co1 ~ Co2) unit acts as a T-shaped node; the (Co3 ~ Co3ii) unit acts as a four-connecting node. Finally, the 2D sheets stack along the crystallographic a axis to complete the crystal structure.

elements.content: There are seven pairs of CC bonds labeled as A-G; Pairs A-F are within one 2D sheet, and Pair G is between two adjacent sheets (). Of all CC pairs, only one pair of them between the two 2c-bpeb ligands, Pair A, is capable of photoaddition according to Schmidt’s topochemical rules (vide infra).

elements.content: Different pairs of CC bonds in 1. Atoms related by inversion centers are labeled only once. Pairs of CC bonds with distances shorter than 4.2 Å are designated as Pairs A-G. Pairs A-F are within one 2D sheet, and G is between two adjacent sheets.
elements.clean_text: 2  Different pairs of CC bonds in 1. Atoms related by inversion centers are labeled only once. Pairs of CC bonds with distances shorter than 4.2 Å are designated as Pairs A-G. Pairs A-F are within one 2D sheet, and G is between two adjacent sheets.

elements.content: In order to investigate the photochemical behavior, single crystals of 1 were irradiated with UV light for various time periods at room temperature (∼30 °C) and the resulting crystals were quenched at 100 K and their structures determined by X-ray crystallography. These SCSC reactions afforded a series of structure data of crystals receiving different doses of UV irradiation, ranging from 0.1 to 9 h. Subsequent structure analysis confirmed that there were two [2 + 2] photocycloaddition reactions at pairs of CC bonds of Pair A and Pair B. Detailed analysis of the structures between 0 and 0.644 h of irradiation revealed that Pair A, comprising A(I) and A(II), meets Schmidt’s topochemical criteria for [2 + 2] dimerization (hereafter denoted as D 1), while Pair B, consisting of B(I) and B(III), does not. In order for Pair B to undergo the [2 + 2] dimerization, B(III) must isomerize to B(II) (cf. ) to align properly with B(I) (so as to satisfy Schmidt’s rules). (See for conformers I, II, and III.) The isomerization reaction (denoted as I) is instantaneous, followed by [2 + 2] dimerization of B(I) and B(II) (hereafter denoted as D 2).
elements.clean_text: In order to investigate the photochemical behavior, single crystals of 1 were irradiated with UV light for various time periods at room temperature (~30 °C) and the resulting crystals were quenched at 100 K and their structures determined by X-ray crystallography. These SCSC reactions afforded a series of structure data of crystals receiving different doses of UV irradiation, ranging from 0.1 to 9 h. Subsequent structure analysis confirmed that there were two [2 + 2] photocycloaddition reactions at pairs of CC bonds of Pair A and Pair B. Detailed analysis of the structures between 0 and 0.644 h of irradiation revealed that Pair A, comprising A(I) and A(II), meets Schmidt's topochemical criteria for [2 + 2] dimerization (hereafter denoted as D 1), while Pair B, consisting of B(I) and B(III), does not. In order for Pair B to undergo the [2 + 2] dimerization, B(III) must isomerize to B(II) (cf. ) to align properly with B(I) (so as to satisfy Schmidt's rules). (See  for conformers I, II, and III.) The isomerization reaction (denoted as I) is instantaneous, followed by [2 + 2] dimerization of B(I) and B(II) (hereafter denoted as D 2).

elements.content: Further investigation of the data shows that there is a point of demarcation between 0.6 and 0.7 h of UV irradiation, upon which the photodimerization of Pair A is complete and the photodimerization of Pair B commences. An interpolation between these two points yielded the demarcation point at 0.644 h as shown in .
elements.clean_text: Further investigation of the data shows that there is a point of demarcation between 0.6 and 0.7 h of UV irradiation, upon which the photodimerization of Pair A is complete and the photodimerization of Pair B commences. An interpolation between these two points yielded the demarcation point at 0.644 h as shown in .

elements.content: (a) Time dependences of fractions of photodimerization in 1: Curve A for Pair A (y = −0.00628­[1 – exp­(7.884x)] for x ≤ 0.644) and Curve B for Pair B (y = 0.602­[1 – exp­(−3.256­(x – 0.644))] for x ≥ 0.644). Fitted equations are in parentheses; (b) Combining Curves A and B by adding 1.0 to the ordinate of Curve B to show the seamless relay of the two photodimerization reactions.
elements.clean_text: 3  (a) Time dependences of fractions of photodimerization in 1: Curve A for Pair A (y = -0.00628[1 - exp(7.884x)] for x ≤ 0.644) and Curve B for Pair B (y = 0.602[1 - exp(-3.256(x - 0.644))] for x ≥ 0.644). Fitted equations are in parentheses; (b) Combining Curves A and B by adding 1.0 to the ordinate of Curve B to show the seamless relay of the two photodimerization reactions.

elements.content:
UV irradiation for up to 9 h resulted in a maximum of about 60% of [2 + 2] photodimerization of Pair B. No photodimerizations were observed for the other pairs, namely, Pairs C-G.

If we move Curve B upward by adding 1.0 to its ordinate, we see that the two curves combine to form a seamless, integrated, “continuous” curve, as portrayed in b. This is the first indication that there is connection between the two curves, which may be characterized as a domino effect with a triggering mechanism operating at the demarcation point (vide infra).
elements.clean_text:
UV irradiation for up to 9 h resulted in a maximum of about 60% of [2 + 2] photodimerization of Pair B. No photodimerizations were observed for the other pairs, namely, Pairs C-G.

If we move Curve B upward by adding 1.0 to its ordinate, we see that the two curves combine to form a seamless, integrated, "continuous" curve, as portrayed in b. This is the first indication that there is connection between the two curves, which may be characterized as a domino effect with a triggering mechanism operating at the demarcation point (vide infra).

elements.content: We shall now discuss the mechanisms of the two photoreactions. Schmidt’s rules state that the distance d, between centroids of two photoreactive CC bonds must be within a distance of 3.4–4.2 Å and the reactive double bonds of the nearest neighbor molecules must also be aligned in parallel.
elements.clean_text: We shall now discuss the mechanisms of the two photoreactions. Schmidt's rules state that the distance d, between centroids of two photoreactive CC bonds must be within a distance of 3.4-4.2 Å and the reactive double bonds of the nearest neighbor molecules must also be aligned in parallel.

elements.content: In other words, there are three stages of photoreactions for Pairs A and B, as evidenced by the “snapshots” provided by our crystallographic data as a function of irradiation time, as follows. Referring to , Curve A, Stage 1: before 0.644 h of irradiation, A(I) and A(II) of Pair A, with d = 3.729 Å and θ = 3.295° (cf. ), are well suited for photodimerization. However, for Pair B, d = 3.785 Å and θ = 57.73° are unfavorable for photodimerization. Curve B, Stage 2: Photoisomerization of B(III) and B(II) is initiated upon completion of the photodimerization of Pair A at 0.644 h of irradiation. Here B(III) needs to “move” its −CC–pyridyl group to opposite position through either flip of the −CC–pyridyl ring about the C–C bond, or via the “pedal motion” of the −CC– bonds (see ). Obviously, the pedaling mode requires less space, and is sterically more favorable. The d and θ values of Pair B at this stage are not known, but they must have satisfied Schmidt’s rules. Stage 3: Slow photodimerization of B(I) and B(II) of Pair B asymptotically to reach a plateau of ∼60% after 9 h of irradiation.
elements.clean_text: In other words, there are three stages of photoreactions for Pairs A and B, as evidenced by the "snapshots" provided by our crystallographic data as a function of irradiation time, as follows. Referring to , Curve A, Stage 1: before 0.644 h of irradiation, A(I) and A(II) of Pair A, with d = 3.729 Å and θ = 3.295° (cf. ), are well suited for photodimerization. However, for Pair B, d = 3.785 Å and θ = 57.73° are unfavorable for photodimerization. Curve B, Stage 2: Photoisomerization of B(III) and B(II) is initiated upon completion of the photodimerization of Pair A at 0.644 h of irradiation. Here B(III) needs to "move" its -CC-pyridyl group to opposite position through either flip of the -CC-pyridyl ring about the C-C bond, or via the "pedal motion" of the -CC- bonds (see ). Obviously, the pedaling mode requires less space, and is sterically more favorable. The d and θ values of Pair B at this stage are not known, but they must have satisfied Schmidt's rules. Stage 3: Slow photodimerization of B(I) and B(II) of Pair B asymptotically to reach a plateau of ~60% after 9 h of irradiation.

elements.content: Before exploring detailed mechanisms of the photoreactions, it is interesting to analyze Curves A and B quantitively. As it turns out, the photodimerizations of both Pair A and Pair B proceed at an exponential fashion, and can be represented by the same empirical functional form, as follows y = a { 1 − exp [ − b ( x − c ) ] }
elements.clean_text: Before exploring detailed mechanisms of the photoreactions, it is interesting to analyze Curves A and B quantitively. As it turns out, the photodimerizations of both Pair A and Pair B proceed at an exponential fashion, and can be represented by the same empirical functional form, as follows 1     y = a  { 1 - exp  [ - b  ( x - c )  ]  }

elements.content: The least-squares fit of the two sets of experimental data yielded the following five parameters: a 1 = –0.00628, b 1 = −7.884, and c 1 = 0 for Curve A and a 2 = 0.602, b 2 = 3.256, and c 2 = 0.644 for Curve B, as shown in .
elements.clean_text: The least-squares fit of the two sets of experimental data yielded the following five parameters: a 1 = -0.00628, b 1 = -7.884, and c 1 = 0 for Curve A and a 2 = 0.602, b 2 = 3.256, and c 2 = 0.644 for Curve B, as shown in .

elements.content: The two experimental equations thus become: Curve A : y = − 0.00628 [ 1 − exp ( 7.884 x ) ] for x ≤ c = 0.644 Curve B : y = 0.602 ( 1 − exp ( − 3.256 ( x − 0.644 ) ) for x ≥ c = 0.644
elements.clean_text: The two experimental equations thus become: 2     Curve  A : y = - 0.00628  [ 1 - exp  ( 7.884 x )  ]   for  x ≤ c = 0.644      3     Curve  B : y = 0.602 ( 1 - exp  ( - 3.256  ( x - 0.644 )  )   for  x ≥ c = 0.644

elements.content: The parameter c = 0.644 provides a link relating the two curves A and B. It is given by : c = − ln [ ( a 1 − 1 ) / a 1 ] / b 1 It is interesting to note that, though bearing the same functional forms, the behaviors of the two curves are starkly different: Curve A, with its negative parameters, a 1 and b 1, are divergent, rising to its end point (complete dimerization), y = 1, at x = c, whereas Curve B, with its positive parameters, a 2 and b 2, are convergent, slowly converges asymptotically to the maximum degree of dimerization of a 2 = 0.602.
elements.clean_text: The parameter c = 0.644 provides a link relating the two curves A and B. It is given by : 4     c = -   ln [ ( a   1   - 1 ) /   a   1   ] /   b   1      It is interesting to note that, though bearing the same functional forms, the behaviors of the two curves are starkly different: Curve A, with its negative parameters, a 1 and b 1, are divergent, rising to its end point (complete dimerization), y = 1, at x = c, whereas Curve B, with its positive parameters, a 2 and b 2, are convergent, slowly converges asymptotically to the maximum degree of dimerization of a 2 = 0.602.

elements.content: The physical significance of the divergent Curve A is that the photodimerization of Pair A is “accelerating” as the reaction proceeds while the exact opposite is true for the photodimerization of Pair B wherein the reaction is impeded or constricted as it proceeds. We shall come back to this point in the discussion of the mechanism.
elements.clean_text: The physical significance of the divergent Curve A is that the photodimerization of Pair A is "accelerating" as the reaction proceeds while the exact opposite is true for the photodimerization of Pair B wherein the reaction is impeded or constricted as it proceeds. We shall come back to this point in the discussion of the mechanism.

elements.content:
Other CC double-bond-pairs, Pairs C-G in 1, remain relatively intact throughout the three stages.

We now wish to propose a molecular triggering mechanism for this three-stage photochemical reaction. depicts the snapshots of the triggering action. Shown here are the shortest C···C van der Waals distances (<3.5 Å) between A(II) and the undimerized B(III) (Table S2) as well as the dimerized B(II) in crystals 1, 5, 6, and 7 for the UV irradiation time t = 0, 0.55, 0.6, and 0.7 h, respectively.

Other CC double-bond-pairs, Pairs C-G in 1, remain relatively intact throughout the three stages.

We now wish to propose a molecular triggering mechanism for this three-stage photochemical reaction.  depicts the snapshots of the triggering action. Shown here are the shortest C⋅⋅⋅C van der Waals distances (<3.5 Å) between A(II) and the undimerized B(III) (Table S2) as well as the dimerized B(II) in crystals 1, 5, 6, and 7 for the UV irradiation time t = 0, 0.55, 0.6, and 0.7 h, respectively.

elements.content: Shortest C···C van der Waals distances (<3.5 Å) between A(II) and B(III) in crystals 1, 5, and 6, and between A(II) and B(II) in 7, for irradiation times of t = 0, 0.55, 0.6, and 0.7 h, respectively. The undimerized fractions are listed in Table S2. Color codes for conformers: I, bright green; dimerized I, green; II, light blue; dimerized II, blue; III, pink. (Ellipsoid probability 30%, hydrogen atoms are omitted. N atoms are in dark blue.)
elements.clean_text: 4  Shortest C⋅⋅⋅C van der Waals distances (<3.5 Å) between A(II) and B(III) in crystals 1, 5, and 6, and between A(II) and B(II) in 7, for irradiation times of t = 0, 0.55, 0.6, and 0.7 h, respectively. The undimerized fractions are listed in Table S2. Color codes for conformers: I, bright green; dimerized I, green; II, light blue; dimerized II, blue; III, pink. (Ellipsoid probability 30%, hydrogen atoms are omitted. N atoms are in dark blue.)

elements.content: It is rationalized that as Pair A photodimerizes, A(II) pushes against the undimerized B(III) as evidenced by the shortest C···C van der Waals (vdW) contacts decreasing from 3.261 Å in crystal 1, through crystals 2–5, to 2.909 and 2.968 Å in crystal 6 at 0.6 h of irradiation. The latter values are significantly below the normal vdW contacts of 3.4 Å. In the process, the crystal lattice strain continues to build up until it reaches the critical (demarcation) point at 0.644 h of irradiation, upon which all A(II) were dimerized and retracted from the undimerized B(III). At this point, the reaction cavity for B(III) opens up, allowing it to photoisomerize to B(II) which (upon satisfying Schmidt’s rules) immediately photodimerizes with the neighboring B(I). This begins to relieve the crystal lattice strain and the shortest C···C van der Waals distance between dimerized A(II) and undimerized B(III) increases to 3.904 Å in crystal 7, and continues to increase, through crystals 8–13, to 4.130 Å in crystal 14. This relaxation of van der Waals repulsion and relief of crystal strain continues until it reaches the plateau of 60% dimerization of B(I) and B(II) at 9 h of irradiation (cf. , Figure S17).
elements.clean_text: It is rationalized that as Pair A photodimerizes, A(II) pushes against the undimerized B(III) as evidenced by the shortest C⋅⋅⋅C van der Waals (vdW) contacts decreasing from 3.261 Å in crystal 1, through crystals 2-5, to 2.909 and 2.968 Å in crystal 6 at 0.6 h of irradiation. The latter values are significantly below the normal vdW contacts of 3.4 Å. In the process, the crystal lattice strain continues to build up until it reaches the critical (demarcation) point at 0.644 h of irradiation, upon which all A(II) were dimerized and retracted from the undimerized B(III). At this point, the reaction cavity for B(III) opens up, allowing it to photoisomerize to B(II) which (upon satisfying Schmidt's rules) immediately photodimerizes with the neighboring B(I). This begins to relieve the crystal lattice strain and the shortest C⋅⋅⋅C van der Waals distance between dimerized A(II) and undimerized B(III) increases to 3.904 Å in crystal 7, and continues to increase, through crystals 8-13, to 4.130 Å in crystal 14. This relaxation of van der Waals repulsion and relief of crystal strain continues until it reaches the plateau of 60% dimerization of B(I) and B(II) at 9 h of irradiation (cf. , Figure S17).

elements.content:
This rationale, based on the local structure of van der Waals contacts, is further corroborated by changes in “reaction cavity” and unit cell dimensions as shown in SI (Figure S15, Table S3).

It is not difficult to understand that an expansion of reaction cavity will facilitate the photochemical reactions. depicts the space-filling models of the “reaction cavities” for Pair B of 1, 6, and 14, after UV irradiation time t = 0, 0.6, and 9 h, respectively. These figures clearly show the enlargement of the reaction cavities (from green to orange contours) of pair B as the photodimerization of Pair A proceeds.
elements.clean_text:
This rationale, based on the local structure of van der Waals contacts, is further corroborated by changes in "reaction cavity" and unit cell dimensions as shown in SI (Figure S15, Table S3).

It is not difficult to understand that an expansion of reaction cavity will facilitate the photochemical reactions.  depicts the space-filling models of the "reaction cavities" for Pair B of 1, 6, and 14, after UV irradiation time t = 0, 0.6, and 9 h, respectively. These figures clearly show the enlargement of the reaction cavities (from green to orange contours) of pair B as the photodimerization of Pair A proceeds.

elements.content: “Reaction cavity” for Pair B in (a) crystal 1 at UV irradiation t = 0 h; (b) crystal 6 at t = 0.6 h; and (c) crystal 14 at t = 9 h (showing the van der Waals surfaces of the reaction cavities as green, green/orange, and orange contours).
elements.clean_text: 5  "Reaction cavity" for Pair B in (a) crystal 1 at UV irradiation t = 0 h; (b) crystal 6 at t = 0.6 h; and (c) crystal 14 at t = 9 h (showing the van der Waals surfaces of the reaction cavities as green, green/orange, and orange contours).

elements.content: In addition to “spatial demand” mentioned above, another factor, the “dimension demand”, is also critical. For 2c-bpeb, the average length of conformation I is slightly shorter after photoaddition (Table S4, S5). As a result of the dimerization of Pair A, the two 2c-bpeb ligands get closer together, leaving more space for the “reaction cavity” of Pair B. Unfortunately, at the same time, the “reaction cavity” becomes shorter, which is unfavorable for the isomerization of Pair B from III to II.
elements.clean_text: In addition to "spatial demand" mentioned above, another factor, the "dimension demand", is also critical. For 2c-bpeb, the average length of conformation I is slightly shorter after photoaddition (Table S4, S5). As a result of the dimerization of Pair A, the two 2c-bpeb ligands get closer together, leaving more space for the "reaction cavity" of Pair B. Unfortunately, at the same time, the "reaction cavity" becomes shorter, which is unfavorable for the isomerization of Pair B from III to II.

elements.content: For 1c-bpeb, the average length of conformation I is 14.93 Å, and III is 12.30 Å. Upon UV irradiation, conformation III isomerizes to II, and then dimerizes; the length changes to 13.02 Å. The large length difference between conformer I and II causes strong tension in the formed dimer. The length demand for 1c-bpeb from III to II becomes increasingly critical with the reaction progresses. These two opposite trends are operative throughout the isomerization of III to II and the subsequent dimerization of Pair B.
elements.clean_text: For 1c-bpeb, the average length of conformation I is 14.93 Å, and III is 12.30 Å. Upon UV irradiation, conformation III isomerizes to II, and then dimerizes; the length changes to 13.02 Å. The large length difference between conformer I and II causes strong tension in the formed dimer. The length demand for 1c-bpeb from III to II becomes increasingly critical with the reaction progresses. These two opposite trends are operative throughout the isomerization of III to II and the subsequent dimerization of Pair B.

elements.content: Finally, there was a significant change in the cell volume as a function of UV irradiation time. As depicted in Figure S16, from 0.4 to 0.6 h of UV irradiation, corresponding to about 25% to 100% of [2 + 2] photoaddition of Pair A, there is an abrupt increase in the crystal volume, viz., from 4290 to 4370 Å3), that is, an expansion of 1.9% in the cell volume, or 80 Å3 (cf. Table S3). Upon completion of photodimerization of Pair A at 0.644 h of UV irradiation, photodimerization of Pair B was triggered, allowing photoisomerization of Pair B to take place (via pedaling mechanism from configuration III to II).
elements.clean_text: Finally, there was a significant change in the cell volume as a function of UV irradiation time. As depicted in Figure S16, from 0.4 to 0.6 h of UV irradiation, corresponding to about 25% to 100% of [2 + 2] photoaddition of Pair A, there is an abrupt increase in the crystal volume, viz., from 4290 to 4370 Å3), that is, an expansion of 1.9% in the cell volume, or 80 Å3 (cf. Table S3). Upon completion of photodimerization of Pair A at 0.644 h of UV irradiation, photodimerization of Pair B was triggered, allowing photoisomerization of Pair B to take place (via pedaling mechanism from configuration III to II).

elements.content: The fact that Curve A is divergent while Curve B is convergent provided a clue to the mechanism of the relaying and trigger pulling effects. In the scenario of the three-stage photochemical reactions, Pair A photodimerizes first. As the reaction proceeds, the reaction Cavity A expands, which not only accelerates its dimerization, but also pushes against the adjoining reaction Cavity B, causing it to shrink a little first (about 6% in volume). Only when dimerization of Pair A is close to completion will the reaction Cavity B bounce back to its original size. The spatial proximity (indeed butting against each other) of the two reaction cavities, Cavities A and B, allows the physical (most likely mechanical in nature) initiation of the photoreactions of Pair B within Cavity B. At the relay point (0.644 h of irradiation), photoisomerization and -dimerization of Pair B are triggered and Cavity B abruptly expanded by 8% in volume. Thereafter, as the dimerization of Pair B proceeds, Cavity B gradually contracts, impeding further reactions until it reaches the plateau of a 2 = 0.6, or 60% dimerized, at 2 h of irradiation. At 9 h of irradiation, Cavity B has shrunk to its original size.
elements.clean_text: The fact that Curve A is divergent while Curve B is convergent provided a clue to the mechanism of the relaying and trigger pulling effects. In the scenario of the three-stage photochemical reactions, Pair A photodimerizes first. As the reaction proceeds, the reaction Cavity A expands, which not only accelerates its dimerization, but also pushes against the adjoining reaction Cavity B, causing it to shrink a little first (about 6% in volume). Only when dimerization of Pair A is close to completion will the reaction Cavity B bounce back to its original size. The spatial proximity (indeed butting against each other) of the two reaction cavities, Cavities A and B, allows the physical (most likely mechanical in nature) initiation of the photoreactions of Pair B within Cavity B. At the relay point (0.644 h of irradiation), photoisomerization and -dimerization of Pair B are triggered and Cavity B abruptly expanded by 8% in volume. Thereafter, as the dimerization of Pair B proceeds, Cavity B gradually contracts, impeding further reactions until it reaches the plateau of a 2 = 0.6, or 60% dimerized, at 2 h of irradiation. At 9 h of irradiation, Cavity B has shrunk to its original size.

elements.content: In conclusion, an unusual series of sequential reactions was observed in single-crystal-to-single-crystal (SCSC) photochemical reactions of MOF 1 as a function of UV irradiation time. The most striking observation is the domino phenomenon and the precise relay timing caused by the triggering effect exerted by Pair A on Pair B at the demarcation point. The triggering mechanism is believed to be stereochemical in nature. Moreover, this work provides the first direct evidence for the dynamic changes of a sequence of SCSC photochemical reactions involving dimerization of one pair inducing isomerization and dimerization of another.
elements.clean_text: In conclusion, an unusual series of sequential reactions was observed in single-crystal-to-single-crystal (SCSC) photochemical reactions of MOF 1 as a function of UV irradiation time. The most striking observation is the domino phenomenon and the precise relay timing caused by the triggering effect exerted by Pair A on Pair B at the demarcation point. The triggering mechanism is believed to be stereochemical in nature. Moreover, this work provides the first direct evidence for the dynamic changes of a sequence of SCSC photochemical reactions involving dimerization of one pair inducing isomerization and dimerization of another.

metadata.title:
First Observation of Unusual Domino Effect and Triggering
Mechanism of Sequential Single-Crystal-to-Single-Crystal Photochemical
Reactions in a Metal–Organic Framework with Multiple Photoreactive
Centers
